bibliographic_metadata.Title: Mineral Prospectivity Mapping Based on a Novel Self-Ensembling Graph Convolutional Network
bibliographic_metadata.Author: Yonghang Lou, Yue Liu

abstract: The graph convolutional network (GCN) has proven to be a powerful tool for exploration criterion identification and mineral prospectivity analysis. However, the graph convolution of the GCN can result in over-smoothing of output features, undermining the reliability of mineral prospectivity mapping (MPM). To address this, we introduce a novel model, the self-ensembling graph convolutional network (SEGCN), which integrates the mean teacher model with a GCN for MPM. A case study for tungsten polymetallic prospectivity analysis in the Nanling belt, China, demonstrates that the SEGCN model significantly outperforms conventional models in mapping tungsten polymetallic prospectivity.
methodology: supervised > deep learning > graph neural network (GNN); supervised > deep learning > CNN; supervised > tree-based > random forest; supervised > kernel-based > support vector machine
key_points: Introduction of a novel SEGCN model for mineral prospectivity mapping.
Case study conducted in the Nanling belt, China, focusing on tungsten polymetallic deposits.
SEGCN model outperforms conventional models like GCN, CNN, RF, and SVM.
Integration of multi-source geospatial datasets enhances model performance.
Robustness of the SEGCN model is improved through a perturbation strategy.
